questions.question_text:
A company has a Microsoft 365 subscription and a Microsoft Azure support plan.
You need to implement only Azure services for which Microsoft provides technical support.
Which two types of services and features can you implement? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content: A and C are correct - Support for Preview services and features is provided only for “Public Preview” programs. Other non-Public Preview and/or Beta services may be supported through our forums or other channels. Azure Support plans do not cover non-Public Previews services.

https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/support/legal/preview-supplemental-terms/
A, C correct

I didn't find any information regarding support or not for targeted release ...
However for public preview it's mentionned that there is no SLA but support will manage ticket
A and C for sure
general and public is correct

Public preview – During this phase we allow any customer with the proper Azure AD license to evaluate the new feature. Microsoft Customer Support Services will supply support services during this phase, but normal service level agreements do not apply.
Correct A,C

Since we can be certain one of the answers is General availability, only one of the others can be true.

Apparently it is Public Preview:

"Public preview – During this phase we allow any customer with the proper Azure AD license to evaluate the new feature. Microsoft Customer Support Services will supply support services during this phase, but normal service level agreements do not apply."

https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/support/legal/preview-supplemental-terms/
A & B is the correct answer

A and C
https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/support/plans/response/

comments.content:
Wrong.
A and C are correct.

discussion.content:
A and B,
PREVIEWS ARE PROVIDED "AS-IS," "WITH ALL FAULTS," AND "AS AVAILABLE," AND ARE EXCLUDED FROM THE SERVICE LEVEL AGREEMENTS AND LIMITED WARRANTY. Previews may not be covered by customer support
https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/support/legal/preview-supplemental-terms/

Azure Support plans do not cover non-Public Previews services. Generally, Azure paid support plans provide technical support for services and features in Public Preview. Some exceptions to the Public Preview support coverage applies, and services/features not covered on your support plan can be found here.
Microsoft does not provide technical support during the public phase, so the answers should be A, B

comments.content:
Correction:

I mixed up a bit between support and SLA.
Microsoft do support during the preview phase:

Public preview – during this phase we allow any customer with the proper Azure AD license to evaluate the new feature. Microsoft Customer Support Services will supply support services during this phase, but normal service level agreements do not apply.

So the correct answer: A and C

discussion.content: OK https://learn.microsoft.com/es-es/microsoft-365/commerce/billing-and-payments/pay-for-your-subscription?view=o365-worldwide
B) I do not see the automatic bank transfer on the payment page, and wire transfer need credit check and 6 months payment history. Can U link it if you find please?

Microsoft Enterprise Agreement and Microsoft Enterprise Subscription Agreement are commitment-based licensing agreements for commercial organizations signing a new enrollment with 500 or more users/devices* and government organizations with 250 or more users/devices.

comments.content: You can use a credit or debit card, or bank account to pay for your subscription. In some cases, you can pay by invoice, using check or electronic funds transfer (EFT). If you have a billing profile, your options are slightly different

discussion.content: surely correct

questions.question_text:
A company that has 50 employees plans to purchase a Microsoft 365 Business subscription.
Which two payment methods are available? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content: A certainly is the answer but this name “Microsoft 365 Business” has been changed to Microsoft 365 Business Premium.

comments.content: i think It's not meant as a specific license like in c and d, but in a more general expression.

discussion.content:
A is correct.

Also be mindful of the amount of users.. the question specifically tells you the user count (250) - Business (Premium) is viable up to 300 users which in some other questions tries to catch you out.

Microsoft Business... Only Business Premium allows you to manage devices...
So if it is Microsoft Business Premium - agree with the answer otherwise Microsoft Office E3.

https://www.microsoft.com/en-sg/microsoft-365/business/microsoft-365-business-premium?activetab=pivot%3aoverviewtab:
"Microsoft 365 Business Premium was purpose built for small and medium-sized businesses with under 300 users."

A is the answer

This is correct:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office365/servicedescriptions/office-365-platform-service-description/office-365-plan-options

questions.question_text:
A small advertising company has 250 employees.
You need to migrate all users to Microsoft 365 and meet the following requirements:
✑ Provide a user-centric licensing solution for all users.
✑ Manage devices from a single location.
✑ Minimize licensing costs.
Which licensing model should you use?

You are the Microsoft 365 administrator for a company.
A user experiences an issue with SharePoint Online.
You need to resolve the issue.
Which two options can you use? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content:
"Support is available both online through the Microsoft 365 admin center and by telephone"

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office365/servicedescriptions/office-365-platform-service-description/support
No support available via SharePoint admin center or Portal. B&C correct!
B and C as kindly provided by TMW for the link and key sentence
BC correct answer

choices.D: Create a service request from the SharePoint portal.
choices.B: Contact Microsoft technical support by telephone.
choices.A: Go to the SharePoint admin center and create a support request.
choices.C: Create a new service request from the Microsoft 365 admin center.

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
A company subscribes to Microsoft 365.
You need to ensure that all administrators receive email notifications about potential service disruptions.
Which three options in the Edit Message center preferences dialog box should you select? To answer, select the appropriate items in the dialog box in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content: The whole question is confusing!
Bill, is this a joke to you?
I think, this is the key: "receive email notifications about potential service disruptions". Major updates can lead to system interruption (as we experience sometimes).
This is just a bad question, if all of your admins are in one distribution list then you don't need additional email addresses.

Do not understand. This is the question: You need to ensure that all administrators receive email notifications about potential service disruptions.
And the answer is to receive Major Updates for Service Disruptions?

The question is which three options should you select in the Edit message center
The answer is
 - Select "Send me emails for major updates (switch it from off to one)
 - Select "Other email addresses" (Check the box)
 -Enter up to two email addresses under the *other email addresses
Same here...
I do not undertstand this either, no idea
I did not even understand the question :D how am I suppose to find correct answer loolll?
